709751f.text:
Seventh Avenue, west side, south from West 33rd to 31st Street's, showing the excavation for the Pennsylvania Railroad Station. This will occupy this entire two square blocks; Eighth Avenue being on the right. The additional excavation in the right center is for the power house that will be located on the opposite side of 31st Street. The R. C. Church and School of St. John the Baptist appear at the left. The school is on 31st Street and the church on 30th Street.
About 1907
Ewing Galloway

709739f-a.text:
Seventh Ave., at the S.E. corner of West 31st Street. The Hotel Governor Clinton will be erected here (1928-29).
August 20, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

730206f-b.title: General view - 7th Avenue - Northwest.
730206f-b.text:
383Seventh Avenue, (Equitable Life Assurance Co Building), east side,from W.31st to 32nd Streets. (general view northwestward).

A view across w. 34th Street towards the North (Hudson) River, In the foreground is a car parking lot between 33rd and 34th Street which will in the near future be a greyhound bus Terminal. Beyond same appears the excavation for the 40 storied hotel New Yorker Printing Crafts Building and the 18 story J.C.Penney Corporation Building No. 241 W. 34th Street. Behind same, on the south side of buildings forming a portion of the garment center that clusters
around Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

April 2, 1928
Views: 1-2-3
P.L. Sperr

730206f-a.title: General view - 7th Avenue - Northwest.
730206f-a.text:

Beyond same appears the excavation for the 40 storied hotel New Yorker Printing Crafts Building and the 18 story J.C.Penney Corporation Building No. 241 W. 34th Street. Behind same, on the south side of buildings forming a portion of the garment center that clusters

Beyond same appears the excavation for the 40 storied hotel New Yorker Printing Crafts Building and the 18 story J.C.Penney Corporation Building No. 241 W. 34th Street. 730207f-a.title: General view - 7th Avenue - Northeast.
730207f-a.text:
383 Seventh Avenue, (Equitable Life Assurance Co. Building), east side, from W. 31st to 32nd Streets. (general view northeastward).
A view over Gimbel's and Macy's roofs towards the Fifth Avenue zone,to show there the steel frame work of the skyscraper No. 10 E. 40th Street. At the left, under the steam cloud is the New York Times Building with its distinctive. tower.
April 2, 1928
P. L. Sperr

712009f-a.text:
W. 31st Street (foreground) between Seventh and Eighth (left) Avenues, showing the south entrance to the Pennsylvania Station on the north side of this thoroughfare. Photographers vantage point is No. 352 Seventh Avenue and from which he is viewing northwestward to show higher structures on the north side of W. 33rd Street, west from Eighth Avenue. Of these,the 22 storied Printing Crafts Building is outstanding and occupies the entire west side frontage of Eighth Avenue from 33rd to 34th Streets. At the left appears the quadrangular Post Office.

May 3, 1928

P.L. Sperr

Seventh avenue, west side, north from and including 34th Street, taken from the Equitable Life Insurance Building, Seventh Avenue,
east side, from 31st to 32nd Streets.
April 2, 1928

712007f-a.text:
212-204 West 31st Street, west of and adjoining the S.W. corner of Seventh Avenue. This is the School of St. John the Baptist.
March 18, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

709754f-a.text:
Seventh Ave., west side, north from West 31st, to and including West 34th Streets, showing the Pennsylvania Railroad Station, as it extends to West 33rd Street. In the right background is seen the Nelson Tower,
between West 34th and West 35th Streets.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Neg. No. 52

709741f.text:
Hotel Governor Clinton, Seventh Avenue at S. E. corner of 31st Street.
1929.
Knickerbocker Photo Service.

709742f.text:
Seventh Avenue, west side, from W. 31st to 33rd Street, showing the automobile runway at Pennsylvania Station. The station proper is on the left; W. 31st Street on the right, and 7th Avenue in the background.
1939
Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Ales. Alland, IRGV.

Slide 257
